Posts.Content: Nov 26, 2010 07:02AM DJ64 wrote: Dear Janis, I agree 100% that for some people depression medication is a must, a lifesaving one.  There is never any shame to take any drug for a medical condition.  I have a son who is bipolar and my first question to him is alway, "your taking your meds, right?".   I fully understand where you are coming from and it is important for you to take medication.  Having watch my son go through "hell" with his condition I am a fervent believer. It was the blanket statement I was objecting. Totally wish you the best Janis, your boat in life isn't an easy rowing. Best, DJ
Posts.Title: Why can't I stop crying? Cynthia1962 DJ64

Posts.Content: Nov 24, 2010 05:48AM DJ64 wrote: Dear Fitztwin, I don't think that "antidepressants and sleep aids are a must and should come with every newly dx patient".   Beside stage IV, I have many medical conditions some that threaten to make me blind, another that will lead to a wheel chair and other debilitating conditions.  I have always work during all my treatments.  I return to work as quickly as possible after surgeries, I have had 20 of them.  Not all were major, but they did require that bracing yourself before and during recovery. The best thing to do is realize that this is the hand fate gave you.  Play it the best way possible.   You can cry, whine and etc, as long as it doesn't become a habit.  Seek counseling if one needs it.  I have always found that the best helping hand is at the end of my own arm.  This has kept sane with the ability to go with the punches.  Sort of like that punching bag little kids have.  Punch it down and it comes right back up.  I am in my 16th year from dx.  I Best, DJ
Posts.Title: Why can't I stop crying? Cynthia1962 DJ64

Posts.Content: Nov 24, 2010 05:56AM DJ64 wrote: Dear Cynthia, It is good to grieve, part of the process of a diagnose of stage IV and a car accident.  You are hormonal positive and that is a good dx.  I am in my 16th years since diagnose.  BC Mets is not an immediate death sentence as with some other types of cancer. Let your husband deal with the insurance companies.   Sometimes bad things happen for no reason at all.  Prior to my original dx, I had a minor surgery that turned into a staph infection that nearly took my life.  Then the dx, for a year I felt what it might be like to step into hell.  Life did right itself eventually.  I have lots of other medical conditions and the best way to deal with it all is to just keep moving.  You will adjust and enjoy life again.  I went on Arimidex for my 3rd recurrence and then had the time of my life.  I travelled and did everything I wanted to do.  Good thing I did, as I can't these days.  So be patient in a little while you will be living your new norm. To early for Arimidex to show side effects.  Your crying because of the double whammy. Best to you on this journey, DJ
Posts.Title: Why can't I stop crying? Cynthia1962 DJ64

Posts.Content: Jul 17, 2009 02:45PM DJ64 wrote: Hi, I was on Faslodex since August of '08 for my widespread pulmonary and pleural metastasis.  In March, there was progression and I went on Femara.  My June ct scan had me stable and the radiologist commented that it looks like whatever treatment I was on was working.  I have used Tamoxifen and Arimidex.  Like you, I did not fail Arimidex, at that time I had been NED for 5 years on the drug and my oncologist suggested I go off.  I did and here I am. I like Arimidex better than Femara.  Since Femara seems to be working, I will take "stable" and continue with this wonderful drug. My vote is to go for Femara rather than chemotherapy.  Much easier to pretend you are normal without all the other side effects from toxic drugs. Best, DJ

Posts.Content: Oct 2, 2011 12:07PM DJ64 wrote: After dosing off at the wheel of my car, I was recommended for a sleep study.  Sure enough, the tech showed me how often I woke up at night.  I had apologize for not sleeping and he told me I did, it just felt like I didn't.  That was why I was so tired.    I have a small throat so intubation for surgery usually done going down my nose.  Since using a cpap device I have not had any episodes of dosing off while driving.  I feel it helps me breath better with lung mets so I like my device.  Couldn't live without it. DJ

Posts.Content: Jan 16, 2010 07:52PM DJ64 wrote: Robin, I used the pill form of Methotrexate for my autoimmune diseases since the summer of 2007.  I began with 3, then 7 and then 10 a week.   I began decreasing the pills until I reached 5 pills and my autoimmune problems were NED.  Five pills proved to be to low to keep my autoimmune problems under control,  so I went back to 10 pills.  I began having nausea last summer.  My autoimmune specialist changed me over to an  injection once a week.  I have 36 hours of blah!  Fatigue is a problem, but I am not certain that Methotrexate should have all the blame.  I do have a lot of other meds that can add to this problem.  I was dx with widespread pulmonary and pleura metastasis a year after starting Methotrexate.   I did have the cough before starting the drug which I totally ignored.  I used Faslodex until progression and presently taking Femara.  I've have used Tamo and Arimidex as hormonal.  I was hoping your estradiol would work for you.  As I plan on doing the same when Femara fails.  I shall watch your new drug combo with interest.  I do hope that these drugs will give you many years. Best wishes, DJ

In your case, it might have been there all along but, the radiologist just didn't mention that area in his results until it progressed. Best to you.

Posts.Content: Oct 4, 2009 09:17AM DJ64 wrote: Dear Kristom3, Only 3% survive stage IV breast cancer.   All the positive thinking will not change the cellular make up of this disease.  It's physiology.  Hoping, wishing, denying isn't going to make any difference. Best, DJ
Posts.Title: Anyone 10 or 20 year surviror at this Stage TLF Padiddle

Posts.Content: Sep 2, 2009 06:26AM DJ64 wrote: When I divorced my attorney advised that in my will, I should give everything to my mother to administer on behalf of my children.   My ex husband would not have any of it in his control.   When I went back to court in order to gain full rights to my children's health care, my ex stated requested more time with the children.  The judge refused to instruct my teenager (age 16) to see his father.   However, the younger (11 yrs old) at the time had to visit his father.   These visits didn't last because his father didn't really want him all the time the court gave him.  He really only wanted to upset me.    The first real visit (6 weeks) and my 11 year was back home in less than a week.   More than likely your ex wants to upset you in not giving up his rights to the children.  The  reality of supporting and caring for children full time, alone, will be more than he can handle.  Your sister will end up caring for your children, should you die before they become of age.   See a lawyer right away. DJ

Good luck DJ

Posts.Title: Suddenly NO Insurance/ NO TREATMENTS Sewfinegirl concernedsis

Posts.Content: Jul 6, 2009 08:17AM DJ64 wrote: I am not certain why your friend can't have the tumor surgically removed.  I had a 2+ cm tumor in my armpit and it was surgically removed.  It wasn't the medical choice, it was my choice.  I wanted it out and then they did radiation.  There are lots of reason they will give for not having surgery.  If a lymph node surgical procedure had been done in that area prior to the recurrence.  My tumor had wrapped itself around the large arm vein and was difficult to remove.  Remove it was, but residue did adhere and the radiation was to take care of that problem. See a surgeon about having the tumor remove.  Don't just allow the cancer center to call all the shots.  Everyone has their specialty.  Surgeons will recommend surgery, radiologist will recommend radiation and oncologist will recommend chemotherapy.  See the one who will help your friend best. Good luck
Posts.Title: I just don't FRICKIN understand cindoe cindoe

Posts.Content: Aug 10, 2010 12:58AM DJ64 wrote: It's a long way from mice to women.  Though it is always good to hope remember that breast cancer is not one disease but many, so one size "fits all" isn't going to happen. In 1998, the world was looking at a new approach to cancer which cured mice.  Dr. Judah Folkman's approach called angiogenesis led eventually to the drug Avastin.  However, cancer was not cured in two years.  There was a lot of hype about HER2NEU oncogene too.    If we were mice, we could celebrate.  We aren't so don't pin your hopes on another new theory.  That doesn't mean not to be hopeful, but it does mean don't go "over the top" with it. DJ

Posts.Title: Lung mets sallyyy Cydz

Posts.Content: Nov 17, 2011 08:27PM DJ64 wrote: Tamoxifen does thicken the uterus lining and often leads to bleeding.  I had a problem many years ago.  I had stop the drug due to a recurrence and began Arimidex.  I didn't know which drug was causing the problem.  I had so many endometrial biopsies that I lost count.  I finally found a better gynecologist and he did a D&C - end of problem.  The results was Endometrial hypoplasia with polyps.  I never had a problem again.  Of course, I had already stop Tamoxifen.  My lining was in cm instead of mm. Hope this helps. DJ

I was diagnose in 1994, 17 1/2 years ago.  My first recurrence was in 1999, 2000 and 2008.  The last was the most serious with widespread pulmonary & pleural metastasis, I am ER+ and have had a great response to AI's.  I'm on Femara.  I stop the drug last spring due to progression.  I did not use Estradiol but, allowed my own estrogen to feed the cancer cells.  After 7 months I had a ct scan which showed that it was back in good form.  I'm back on Femara to see if it will work again.  I have used Tamoxifen, Arimidex, Faslodex and Femara. DJ

Posts.Title: i think i have a lung mets sallyyy CoolBreeze

Posts.Content: Aug 10, 2010 11:36AM DJ64 wrote: I am a little more than skeptic about Dr. Tuochy for if you "Google" his name, he isn't exactly unknown in this research.  In my other post, I mentioned the hoopla with angiogenesis which was in 1998 a very different approach in search for the cure.  Dr. Folkman was a very quiet scientist as well as an excellent physician.  He believed in his theory, and it was a good one.  The hype made it sound like a cure.  Only in mice is it a cure, then and now. I also, remember "Taxol" when it was the drug to cure Ovarian Cancer.  It was offered to me in 1994, as another drug, but it was still in Trial, I would have been part of a trial.  At the time, I wanted a sure bet and took an older drug.  Years later, I read the reason for the hoopla was due to the fact it was the first new drug to come out in years.   I do hope it works, but my hopes are tampered with some real doubts. DJ
Posts.Title: Why we can trust Dr. Tuohy's new cancer vaccine Terry3N BaseballFan

Posts.Content: Jan 14, 2012 10:21AM - edited Jan 14, 2012 10:26AM by DJ64 In my 14 year dealing with bc (I had 2 recurrence during those years) a ct/pet scan along with a VATS diagnose me with widespread tumors in both lungs & lining.  I used Faslodex which kept me stable for 7 months.  I am highly ER+ and then went on Femara for 2 years.  Already did Tamoxifen, Arimidex.  Most of all the tumors disappeared though a handful stayed.  I progressed took a drug break (no estradiol).  Recent ct scan showed tumors all returned.   I am back on Femara and hope it will work it wonders again.  I had a pleura effusion that was drained with the VATS and haven't had a problem since.  I am now in my 17th year and in the same age bracket of your mom. The tumor board initially recommended chemotherapy, my oncologist thought I would respond better to hormonal therapy.  Is your mother at all ER or PR positive?  I had chemotherapy when initially diagnose, I never thought it worked.  Tamoxifen didn't either and 4 yrs later I had a recurrence.  My cancer is slow growing.  I wonder if that might not be the case with your mother? On this board a few years ago, I read about a woman whose cancer was similar to mine. She had one of the best known oncologist in this country.  He said because her cancer is unaggressive, chemo works best on quickly dividing cells, her cells were slow.  it was best to keep to hormonal. My original tumor showed a grade of 3 which were fast growing cells.  However, my history shows it to be slow.  My 2nd recurrence was in 2 ribs.  They just showed up again on the recent scan, so it took them 11 years to return.  Figure my cancer is slow.  It's a wild possibility, a real wild card but, if she is ER or PR+, would hormonal work better?  Perhaps she has had them all and that is why the chemotherapy.  I have heard good things about Halavan.  Just a thought.   All my doctors (have a lot of other serious medical issues) find it hard to believe with what showed up in the last recurrence, I was still around.  Don't give up on her, keep trying to find answers.  I wish your mother well on this journey.  She is very fortunate to have such a helpful daughter. Best, DJ

Best to you as start another journey, but your in good company here. DJ
